title: The Danites' Migration
shortSummary: Judges 18 recounts the tribe of Dan's search for a new inheritance due to their incomplete allotment. They spy out the land of Laish, steal Micah's idols and priest, and conquer the city, renaming it Dan. This chapter highlights Israel's spiritual decline and the consequences of idolatry and disobedience during a time without a king.
timeline: c. 1300-1100 BC - Period of the Judges in Israel

keyCharacters.name: Danites
keyCharacters.description: A tribe of Israel seeking to secure their inheritance by migrating to and conquering the city of Laish.

keyCharacters.name: Micah
keyCharacters.description: A man who had made idols and hired a Levite as his priest, whose household is robbed by the Danites.

keyCharacters.name: The Levite Priest
keyCharacters.description: A young Levite serving as Micah's priest who is persuaded to join the Danites and serve as their priest.

keyCharacters.name: Jonathan
keyCharacters.description: Son of Gershom, descendant of Manasseh, who serves as priest for the tribe of Dan after their migration.

definitions.definition: A sacred garment or object used by priests in Israel, often associated with seeking God's guidance.
Household idols or small images used for divination or worship, forbidden by God.
An idol or carved figure representing a god, which is prohibited by the Ten Commandments.
A mountainous region in central Israel, territory of the tribe of Ephraim.

outline.heading: The Danites Seek an Inheritance
outline.description: The tribe of Dan, lacking a full inheritance, sends five valiant men to spy out the land, seeking God's guidance through a Levite priest. This reveals their desire for a new home and reliance on divine counsel.

outline.heading: Report and Mobilization of the Danites
outline.description: The spies find Laish to be a peaceful and vulnerable city, encouraging the tribe to mobilize 600 armed men to take possession. They camp near Kirjathjearim, signaling their strategic planning.

outline.heading: The Theft of Micah’s Idols and Priest
outline.description: The Danite spies steal Micah’s idols and persuade the Levite priest to join them, highlighting Israel’s spiritual corruption and the Levite’s compromised loyalty.

outline.heading: Conquest and Settlement of Laish
outline.description: The Danites attack and destroy Laish, rename it Dan, and establish idolatry with Micah’s graven image, showing their disobedience and the ongoing cycle of sin during the Judges period.

application: Trust in God’s guidance rather than relying on idolatrous or worldly means when making important decisions.
Guard against spiritual compromise by remaining faithful to God’s commands and rejecting idolatry in all forms.
Recognize the dangers of disobedience and the consequences of turning away from God’s established order.
Commit to serving God wholeheartedly rather than seeking personal gain or comfort through ungodly alliances.

keyVerses.text: In those days there was no king in Israel: and in those days the tribe of the Danites sought them an inheritance to dwell in; for unto that day all their inheritance had not fallen unto them among the tribes of Israel.
keyVerses.significance: This verse sets the historical context, emphasizing Israel’s lack of centralized leadership and the Danites’ unsettled status.

keyVerses.text: And the priest said unto them, Go in peace: before the LORD is your way wherein ye go.
keyVerses.significance: The Levite’s blessing reflects a misguided assurance that God is with their plans, despite the sinful actions that follow.

keyVerses.text: And Jonathan, the son of Gershom, the son of Manasseh, he and his sons were priests to the tribe of Dan until the day of the captivity of the land.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the establishment of a hereditary priesthood in Dan, illustrating the tribe’s departure from proper worship centered in the tabernacle.

keyVerses.text: And they set them up Micah's graven image, which he made, all the time that the house of God was in Shiloh.
keyVerses.significance: The continued use of Micah’s idol during the tabernacle’s presence in Shiloh shows the persistence of idolatry and spiritual decline in Israel.
